Authors: Andreasen, MM; Christensen, BJ
Author Full Names: Andreasen, Martin M.; Christensen, Bent Jesper
Article Title: The SR approach: A new estimation procedure for non-linear and non-Gaussian dynamic term structure models
Author Keywords: Bond data; GMM; Non-linear filtering; Non-linear least squares; SMM
Keywords Plus: RECURSIVE ESTIMATION; YIELD CURVE; MOMENTS; INFORMATION; PREMIA
Abstract: This paper suggests a new approach for estimating linear and non-linear dynamic term structure models with latent factors. We impose no distributional assumptions on the factors which therefore may be non-Gaussian. The novelty of our approach is to use many observables (yields or bond prices) in the cross-section dimension. This implies that the latent factors can be determined quite accurately by a sequence of cross-section regressions. We also show how output from these regressions can be used to obtain model parameters by a two- or three-step moment-based estimation procedure. (C) 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Breunig, C
Author Full Names: Breunig, Christoph
Article Title: Goodness-of-fit tests based on series estimators in nonparametric instrumental regression
Author Keywords: Nonparametric regression; Instrument; Linear operator; Orthogonal series estimation; Hypothesis testing; Local alternative; Uniform consistency
Keywords Plus: ASYMPTOTIC NORMALITY; IDENTIFICATION; INFERENCE; VARIABLES; MODEL
Abstract: This paper proposes several tests of restricted specification in nonparametric instrumental regression. Based on series estimators, test statistics are established that allow for tests of the general model against a parametric or nonparametric specification as well as a test of exogeneity of the vector of regressors. The tests' asymptotic distributions under correct specification are derived and their consistency against any alternative model is shown. Under a sequence of local alternative hypotheses, the asymptotic distributions of the tests are derived. Moreover, uniform consistency is established over a class of alternatives whose distance to the null hypothesis shrinks appropriately as the sample size increases. A Monte Carlo study examines finite sample performance of the test statistics. (C) 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Bernas, J; Jelinkova, Z; Moudry, J; Kopecky, M; Moudry, J
Book Editors: Polak, O; Cerkal, R; Belcredi, NB
Author Full Names: Bernas, Jaroslav; Jelinkova, Zuzana; Moudry, Jan, Jr.; Kopecky, Marek; Moudry, Jan
Article Title: MISCANTHUS - POSSIBILITY OF GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSION MITIGATION
Conference Title: 22nd International PhD Students Conference
Conference Location: Mendel Univ, Fac Agron, Brno, CZECH REPUBLIC
Author Keywords: maize; Miscanthus x giganteus; greenhouse gas emissions; Life Cycle Assessment
Keywords Plus: LIFE-CYCLE ASSESSMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; ENERGY; BIOGAS; AGRICULTURE; PRODUCTS; SYSTEMS; YIELD; CO2
Abstract: One of the most important renewable energy source is the energy from phytomass. Recently, there has been significant development of growing energy crops as raw materials for biogas production in biogas plants (BGP). In the conditions of the Czech Republic, it is mainly maize. Maize cultivation itself and especially technical processes associated with it participate significantly in the anthropogenic emission production. One of the ways of reducing these emissions is the substitution of maize with another plant suitable for such purposes. This may be Miscanthus x giganteus. This article presents the results of monitoring of emission load resulting from the cultivation of maize (Zea mays L.) and Miscanthus x giganteus for energy purposes. The tool to determine the level of emission load (expressed in CO(2)e where CO(2)e = 1x CO2 + 23x CH4 + 298x N2O) is the simplified Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) method, respectively its Climate Impact category. For the calculations, the SIMAPro software and the ReCiPe Midpoint (H) method is used. The results show that within the cultivation of Miscanthus x giganteus for energy purposes, the CO(2)e production decreases during the second year of cultivation by nearly 40% per 1 kg of dry matter. While in comparison with maize, it is almost half production of CO(2)e per the production unit depending on the yields and energy inputs.

Authors: Bu, JJ; Wang, XB
Book Editors: Qi, E; Shen, J; Dou, R
Author Full Names: Bu, Jian-jun; Wang, Xing-bo
Article Title: ADAMS Modeling and Dynamics Simulation of Mosaic Particle's Motion State
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 21ST INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT 2014
Conference Title: 21st International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management 2014 (IEEM)
Conference Sponsor: CMES, Chinese Ind Engn Inst,Beijing Inst Technol,Tianjin Univ Sci & Technol
Author Keywords: Dynamics vibration; mosaic particles; simulation analysis; three-dimensional modeling
Abstract: According to dynamic movements and vibration of complex conveyer with Mosaic particles, simulation analysis of conveyer is carried out by ADAMS. First, three dimensional model of conveyer was established by the software of solidworks/proe, then it was lead into the software of ADAMS, the model was established by defining restriction, load, rigid-flexible coupling and contact among the parts of conveyer on the virtual machine of ADAMS. At last, the graphics of displacement, velocity of moving mosaic, acceleration of mass center of Mosaic particles were gotten by simulation, which provides the certain foundation for the structure optimization of conveyer machine.

Authors: Chang, LH; Deng, HP
Author Full Names: Chang Li-hua; Deng Hou-ping
Article Title: Research on Risks of Strategy Conversion from OEM to OBM for Chinese Private Processing Trade Enterprises
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: OBM; OEM; risk; strategy conversion
Keywords Plus: COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE; MODEL
Abstract: The transformation and upgrading of processing trade has become an important subject of Chinese foreign trade development. But as one of the main paths, upgrading from OEM to OBM for Chinese private processing trade enterprises is a major strategy conversion with significant strategic risks. Through the establishment of the state-transition model of enterprise strategy system under strategy conversion, by comparing the important characteristic of OEM with that of OBM the required transition and coordination of strategy elements from OEM to OBM was discussed, and from the perspective of state transition the risks of strategy conversion from OEM to OBM were analyzed in the aspects of external environment, resources and capabilities, knowledge, structure, process and coordination. It was discovered that the strategy conversion from OEM to OBM for Chinese private processing trade enterprises is not only the change of strategy itself, but also the integral shift of enterprise strategy systems. It was proposed that enterprises should adopt the appropriate tactics according to their own strengths and the external conditions, carefully deal with various relations and reduce the conversion cost to ensure the success of strategy conversion and that the government should create good external environments for enterprises transformation and upgrading.

Authors: Dong, YC
Author Full Names: Dong Yan-chun
Article Title: Study on the Negotiated Governance Model in Public Crises Based on the Analysis of Chinese-Style NIMBY Conflict
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: the negotiated governance model; NIMBY; public crisis; PX event; SWOT
Abstract: At present public crisis incidents take place frequently in China, and lead to large-scale group events and damage stability and development of the society. Through case studies on the PX events that happened in Xiamen, Dalian, Ningbo and Xianyang recently, we summed up the process of the Chinese-style public crises. It consists of five stages: project approval, construction, protest, work stoppages, and termination (relocation). Based on analysis of causes and harms of the Chinese-style public crises, we created a negotiated governance mode, in which the government, enterprises, residents and social groups took part. Through SWOT analysis of the model, we found clear strategies to improve negotiated governance mode, so as to provide a new path to solve Chinese-style NIMBY conflict.

Authors: Eirini, V
Author Full Names: Eirini, Vlassi
Article Title: Web 2.0 Enhancing Role in Heritage Interpretation Based on Constructivist Learning Theories
Source Title: CULTURAL TOURISM IN A DIGITAL ERA
Book Series Title: Springer Proceedings in Business and Economics
Conference Title: 1st IACuDiT International Conference on Cultural Tourism in a Digital Era
Conference Sponsor: Int Assoc Cultural & Digital Tourism
Author Keywords: Interpretation; Heritage; Web 2.0; Constructivist learning theories; Virtual communities; Social software
Keywords Plus: COMMUNITY
Abstract: The aim of this paper is to reveal Web 2.0 as a meaningful heritage interpretative technique that could be employed in heritage interpretation to improve visitor's experience through the constructivist learning opportunities. Constructivist learning theories involve learner in a participatory meaning-making process to foster deep learning and understanding which is enhanced by Web 2.0 functions. Interpretation is an educational process that aims to reveal meanings and values that lie behind the facts and objects. Interpretation that does not enables interaction among visitor and resource is sterile. As a result there is an interrelation between interpretation and constructivist learning which highlights the value of visitor's participation in the interpretational activities. Web 2.0 is intended to encourage active participation, cooperation and exchange of knowledge and ideas between users. This research presents for functions of Web 2.0 that enhance heritage interpretation: Interaction among users, Content creation and interaction with it, social tagging and Recreation.

Authors: Hu, LX; Xu, Q; Lu, XF; Wang, Q; Fu, M; Qin, HH
Book Editors: Qi, E; Shen, J; Dou, R
Author Full Names: Hu, Lie-xiang; Xu, Qian; Lu, Xiao-fen; Wang, Qiong; Fu, Ming; Qin, Hong-hao
Article Title: Research on Investment Capacity Model for Power Grid Enterprises Research on Investment Capacity Model for Power Grid Enterprises
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 21ST INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT 2014
Conference Title: 21st International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management 2014 (IEEM)
Conference Sponsor: CMES, Chinese Ind Engn Inst,Beijing Inst Technol,Tianjin Univ Sci & Technol
Author Keywords: Calculation model; investment capacity; investment demand; power grid enterprises
Abstract: The power grid investment has the characteristics of huge amount of investment, long payback period, and it is a very big spending of the power grid enterprises. Therefore, it has the very strong practical significance for the power grid enterprises to quantitatively study and accurately grasp their investment capacity, and then formulate a reasonable investment plan, use the financial resources as a whole, make financial benefit play the leading role. In this paper, combined with the financial management theory, a quantitative model is conducted which uses two constraints of target profits and assets liability rate to study the power grid investment capability. The calculation results show that the proposed model can accurately reflect the investment capacity of power grid enterprise, and it has strong applicability. What's more, it provides the scientific basis for power grid enterprises to invest reasonably and increase the rate of return effectively.

Authors: Tran, LH; Tran, DL; Liu, CH
Book Editors: Pham, TML; Soukup, J; Phan, D; Phung, MT
Author Full Names: Lan Huong Tran; Duy Lien Tran; Liu, Ching-Hsiang
Article Title: A Quantitative Investigation of Various Factor Effects on Employee Intention
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2ND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON FINANCE AND ECONOMICS 2015
Conference Title: 2nd International Conference on Finance and Economics (ICFE)
Conference Location: Ton Duc Thang Univ, Ho Chi Minh City, VIETNAM
Conference Sponsor: Corvinus Univ Budapest,Taylors Univ,Nanhua Univ,Univ Econ,Asian Inst Technol,Vysoka Skola Ekonomicka
Author Keywords: Human Resource Management; Employee Retention; Intention to Stay; Intention to Leave; Manual Worker; Blue Collar Worker
Keywords Plus: TURNOVER; RETENTION; MODERATOR; MODEL
Abstract: Employee retention is one of the biggest challenges of human resource management in various organizations especially manufacturing firms due to the high turnover rate and numerous disadvantages which cannot be eliminated. The purpose of this research is to provide recommendations to enhance the employee retention of Dien Quang Company by investigating various factor effects on employees' intention to stay and intention to leave. Therefore, demographic factors, recognition, career development, supervision, and interpersonal relationship were employed to clarify their influences on both intention to stay and intention to leave. Multivariate regression model was used to analyze the correlation between dependent variables and their determinants. 350 blue collar workers of the company participated in the survey but only 302 were qualified for the research sample. The results showed that recognition increases employees' intention to stay but has no significant effect on intention to leave. Career development and supervision have positive impacts on employee intention to stay but negative influences on intention to leave. Besides, interpersonal relationship has a positive effect on intention to leave but insignificant correlation is found with intention to stay. Therefore, it is suggested that the company should focus on enhancing employees' commitment through recognition, career development, and supervision as key elements of their employee retention strategies. Additionally, caring about their personal information to assign them appropriate positions and supports is also recommended. Besides, proposing flexible solutions in helping these employees to have a work-life balance, especially in their interpersonal relationship will also be highlighted. Recommendations are provided for not only Dien Quang Company but also other manufacturing enterprises which operate on same field in Vietnam.

Authors: Li, QQ; Li, XS
Book Editors: Qi, E; Shen, J; Dou, R
Author Full Names: Li, Quan-qing; Li, Xiao-shu
Article Title: Research on the Model of People Being Led Satisfaction Based on Cadre Assessment
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 21ST INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT 2014
Conference Title: 21st International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management 2014 (IEEM)
Conference Sponsor: CMES, Chinese Ind Engn Inst,Beijing Inst Technol,Tianjin Univ Sci & Technol
Author Keywords: Index system; model; people being led; satisfaction
Abstract: At present the common satisfaction models are all to evaluate product or organization, in this paper, it puts forward the satisfaction model which evaluates the individual. Based on the cadre assessment problems in the interior of enterprises and institutions, it proposes the model of people being led satisfaction, and points out the unique difficulties of evaluating the individual. It constructs the two levels index system which includes the whole work of working unit, the work in charge by leaders, leadership qualities ability and employees benefits, etc. And according to the role of leaders in leadership activities, working relations with appraisers, it puts forward the distribution principle of index weight.

Authors: Mazalova, L; Sladek, Z
Book Editors: Polak, O; Cerkal, R; Belcredi, NB
Author Full Names: Mazalova, Lenka; Sladek, Zbysek
Article Title: EFFECT OF PC-3 PROSTATE CANCER CELL LINE SUPERNATANT ON APOPTOSIS IN MACROPHAGES
Conference Title: 22nd International PhD Students Conference
Conference Location: Mendel Univ, Fac Agron, Brno, CZECH REPUBLIC
Author Keywords: prostate; cancer; supernatant; macrophage; apoptosis
Abstract: Particular types of cell death, for example apoptosis, play important role in metastatic processes. Apoptosis is programmed cell death, which is characterised by specific morphological changes. In this study we aimed on topic of affecting of supernatant from prostate cancer cell line PC-3 on a healthy cells of immune system, macrophages concretely. Peripheral blood monocytes were cultivated for 7 days to macrophages. Macrophages were stimulated for 24 hours by lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and cultivated with supernatant for another 24 hours. Preparations were prepared and analysed by light microscopy. Macrophages with normal morphology show the largest rate in our experiment. In samples macrophages + supernatant there was an increase mainly in late stage of apoptosis. A lot of observed cells showed feature of rupture and spillage of cell contents into the microenvironment. In samples macrophages + supernatant + LPS there is a noticeable decline in the incidence of normal morphology compared to the control. This means that effect of cancer cells and their supernatants on macrophages can induce apoptosis on macrophages and thus prevent proper course of immune responses.

Authors: Rehackova, K; Stastna, M
Book Editors: Polak, O; Cerkal, R; Belcredi, NB
Author Full Names: Rehackova, Kristyna; Stastna, Milada
Article Title: THE TRANSFORMATION OF THE CULTURAL LANDSCAPE OF THE VILLAGE OSTOPOVICE
Conference Title: 22nd International PhD Students Conference
Conference Location: Mendel Univ, Fac Agron, Brno, CZECH REPUBLIC
Author Keywords: cultural landscape; landscape changes; Ostopovice; photography; survey; SWOT analysis
Abstract: This paper describes the transformation of Czech cultural landscape in Ostopovice municipality. Firstly, the cultural landscape is depicted in detail and there are identified the specifics of the selected area. Subsequently, there are compared and evaluated changes in the landscape during the past 60 years. Used methods such as scanning, questionnaires and SWOT analysis, including set of three hypotheses, are presented in the methodological section. There is also Ostopovice community and landscape-ecological context characterized in detail within the selected time period. There have been identified conclusive landscape changes over the time comparing historical maps to the present ones. The results of SWOT analysis reflect mainly the opportunities for the land-use in selected area. All hypotheses were confirmed by using selected methods and subsequent evaluation. The results confirm the significant land-use changes in the cultural landscape of the Ostopovice village and the potential for their increase in the future.

Authors: Sun, C; Chen, LW
Author Full Names: Sun Chen; Chen Li-wen
Article Title: An Evaluation Study of Dynamic Housing Affordability Based on Mortgage Loan Setting Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei Region as an Example
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region; housing affordability; housing mortgage loan; income increase
Keywords Plus: AUSTRALIA; MODEL; CHINA
Abstract: The evaluation study of housing affordability is the foundation of reasonably planning of housing supply structure and establishing a improved housing security system. The paper identifies evaluation index by using factor analysis, establishes the evaluation pattern of urban residents' housing affordability and appraises the urban residents' housing affordability in Beijing, Tianjin and Hebei. It is estimated that the cost of purchasing a house in mortgage. loan is lower than renting a house of the same size if the income is increasing and sown payment is affordable. The problem of urban residents' housing affordability in Beijing is the most conspicuous,Tianjin ranking the second and Hebei the last. The government should implement housing security for a family with an income lower than 58,560 in Beijing, 28,992 in Tianjin and 17,856 in Hebei.

Authors: Valente, C
Author Full Names: Valente, Christine
Article Title: Civil conflict, gender-specific fetal loss, and selection: A new test of the Trivers-Willard hypothesis
Author Keywords: Sex ratio; Civil conflict; Fetal loss; Trivers-Willard; Nepal
Keywords Plus: HUMAN SEX-RATIO; DUTCH FAMINE; NEONATAL-MORTALITY; NATURAL-SELECTION; PRENATAL EXPOSURE; PREGNANCY LOSS; LATER LIFE; BIRTH; STRESS; WAR
Abstract: A sizeable economics literature explores the effect of prenatal shocks on later health or socioeconomic status. Work in other disciplines, following the seminal contribution of Trivers and Willard (1973), suggests that prenatal shocks may increase fetal loss and reduce the number of boys relative to girls at birth. This has been largely ignored in the economics literature and could affect the interpretation of estimates of the effect of prenatal shocks and that of gender in other applied economics contexts. This paper analyzes the effect of in utero exposure to a shock - civil conflict in Nepal - on (i) fetal loss, and (ii) gender and (iii) health at birth. Maternal fixed effects estimates show that exposed pregnancies are more likely to result in a miscarriage and in a female birth, but exposed newborns are neither smaller nor more subject to neonatal mortality. Authors: Vrsanska, M; Kumbar, V
Book Editors: Polak, O; Cerkal, R; Belcredi, NB
Author Full Names: Vrsanska, Martina; Kumbar, Vojtech
Article Title: A COMPARISON OF BIURET, LOWRY AND BRADFORD METHODS FOR MEASURING THE EGG'S PROTEINS
Conference Title: 22nd International PhD Students Conference
Conference Location: Mendel Univ, Fac Agron, Brno, CZECH REPUBLIC
Author Keywords: protein; Lowry method; Biuret method; Bradford method; albumen; egg yolk
Abstract: Quantitation of the total protein content in a sample is a critical step in protein analysis. Molecular UV-Vis absorption spectroscopy is very efficient in quantitative analysis such as protein quantitation and has extensive applications in chemical and biochemical laboratories, medicine and food industry. Traditional spectroscopic methods are cheap, easy-working and the most common way to quantitate protein concentrations. This study compares Biuret, Lowry and Bradford methods for measuring hen albumen and egg yolk as protein samples. These methods are commonly used for determination proteins. The Biuret test uses as a reagent: Biuret reagent. For Lowry assay are used four reagents: reagent A, reagent B, reagent C and reagent D. For last method, Bradford, is used as a reagent Coomassie Brilliant Blue G-250. The absorbance was measured at a wavelength of 750 nm for Lowry, 540 nm for Biuret and 595 nm for Bradford assay. The lowest content of proteins was analysed in albumen (0.706 mg.ml(-1)) and egg yolk (0.996 mg.ml(-1)) for Biuret method. According to the Lowry assay, was content of proteins in albumen 0.908 mg.ml(-1) and content in egg yolk was 1.003 mg.ml(-1). The highest content of proteins, which was analysed using method Bradford, was content of protein in albumen 1.125 mg.ml(-1) and content for egg yolk was 1.369 mg.ml(-1).

Authors: Wang, Q; Shi, J; Liang, F
Book Editors: Qi, E; Shen, J; Dou, R
Author Full Names: Wang, Qian; Shi, Jin; Liang, Feng
Article Title: Study on Measure of Matching Degree between Management Platform and Information Platform in the Context of IS Success Based on Kullback-Leibler Divergence
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 21ST INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT 2014
Conference Title: 21st International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management 2014 (IEEM)
Conference Sponsor: CMES, Chinese Ind Engn Inst,Beijing Inst Technol,Tianjin Univ Sci & Technol
Author Keywords: Evaluation of IS success; IT project management; Kullback-Leibler Divergence; modeling based-on information flow; measure of matching degree
Keywords Plus: SYSTEMS
Abstract: Aim to solve the lack of quantitative method on measure of information system success and IT project management, the article advance the principle and related technique on measure of matching degree between management platform(MP) and information platform(IP) based-on Kullback-Leibler divergence(KLD). Firstly, it discuss the essential of enterprise modeling technique based on information flow, and then introduce and analysis the Critical Nodes which will contribute to build the architecture of evaluation index system from the management reference model which derives from enterprise modeling process. After that, it investigates how to describe the probability, distribution and parameter of the uncertainty existing in the Critical Nodes. And then, it gives out the method and procedure on using KLD method to calculate the difference between MP and IP on certain Critical Node and then integrate the whole index value via Analytic Network Process (ANP) method. Finally, it gets the perspective on development and application of the quantitative method.

Authors: Yan, JW; Hu, YG; Wen, JQ
Book Editors: Qi, E; Shen, J; Dou, R
Author Full Names: Yan, Jiawei; Hu, Yaoguang; Wen, Jingqian
Article Title: Game Analysis of Knowledge Resources Transactions
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 21ST INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT 2014
Conference Title: 21st International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management 2014 (IEEM)
Conference Sponsor: CMES, Chinese Ind Engn Inst,Beijing Inst Technol,Tianjin Univ Sci & Technol
Author Keywords: Evaluation; game theory; knowledge resource; trade
Abstract: In order to realize the knowledge transaction in large research organizations, on the basis of the analysis of knowledge resources in large research organizations and research on related and abroad literatures, knowledge resource evaluation index system is established, calculation methods of index and weight are introduced, the model of knowledge seller and buyer is constructed. What's more, three different knowledge transaction modes are illustrated. Knowledge pricing process is explained by game theory model, the transaction price can be calculated using the transaction model. Overall, methods in this paper can increase the research capability and competitiveness of research organizations.

Authors: Yang, ZM; Wang, WP; Yang, YB; Fang, F
Book Editors: Qi, E; Shen, J; Dou, R
Author Full Names: Yang Zhoumu; Wang Wenping; Yang Yibo; Fang Fen
Article Title: An Empirical Study of Environmental Kuznets Curve in China
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 21ST INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT 2014
Conference Title: 21st International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management 2014 (IEEM)
Conference Sponsor: CMES, Chinese Ind Engn Inst,Beijing Inst Technol,Tianjin Univ Sci & Technol
Author Keywords: EKC; economic development; environment pollution; per capita GDP; sulfur dioxide emissions
Keywords Plus: ECONOMIC-GROWTH; EMISSIONS
Abstract: Environment Kuznets Curve (EKC) hypothesis is a classic expression of describing the relationship between economy and environment. Based on the theory of EKC, this paper established an econometric model between economic development and environmental pollution according to the data of sulfur dioxide emission and per capita GDP of China over the period of 1998 to 2012. Regression analysis shows that relationship between the sulfur dioxide emissions and per capita GDP displays a typical N shape, and the present situation of China is at the rising stage after two tunning points. Economic development of China is still at the expense of sacrificing environment to some extend. Pollution has been rising along with the development of economy, and this trend will not change in the short term. Transforming and upgrading from factor driven and capital -driven to innovation-driven is particularly important for economic transformation and upgrading in China.

Authors: Zawadka, J
Author Full Names: Zawadka, Jan
Article Title: Preferences and Behaviors of the Elder People Resting in Valuable Natural Areas
Source Title: CULTURAL TOURISM IN A DIGITAL ERA
Book Series Title: Springer Proceedings in Business and Economics
Conference Title: 1st IACuDiT International Conference on Cultural Tourism in a Digital Era
Conference Sponsor: Int Assoc Cultural & Digital Tourism
Author Keywords: Rural tourism; Agritourism; The elderly; Seniors; Preferences and behaviors of tourists
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to introduce results of the research about preferences and behaviors of the elder people, resting in natural valuable areas. Thus, in the article the profile of an average senior, sightseeing valuable natural areas, was presented and such aspects like motives for choosing this form of tourism (as well as the particular offer), tourists' use of sources of information concerning accommodation, preferred ways of spending leisure time and expectations about diversification and improvement of the offer were discussed. Finally, the analysis of factors implicating surveyed tourists' behaviors and expectations (like level of education and financial status) was made. The research with use of the polling technique was made in summer of 2013 and included 45 participants (tourists) in age of 55 or higher, resting in rural accommodation objects near Kampinos National Park. Identification of preferences and behaviors of people resting in valuable natural areas is crucial to the improvement and adaptation of tourist accommodation offer to the level expected by particular market segments. Such research is also important for authorities of the local communities, as well as people planning touristic and recreational development in valuable natural areas. Previous research was rarely focused on particular age groups, what seems to be vital in such case, because youths, families with babies or seniors have completely different expectations regarding their holidays.

Authors: Zhang, RX; Xue, XL
Author Full Names: Zhang Rui-xue; Xue Xiao-long
Article Title: Analyzing the Formation and Evolution of Engineering Innovation Networks by Using a Modified BA Model
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: attractiveness; BA model; engineering project; innovation network; relativity
Keywords Plus: CONSTRUCTION
Abstract: The effective cooperation relationships among the participants are prerequisites for successful innovation on engineering. Stakeholders' collaborative relationship formed a network, collaborative innovation network. Its formation is very important to improve innovation performance. It's difficult to clarify its formation and evolution completely. This article reports on the study of collaborative innovation network by modifying the Barabasi and Albert (BA) model based on the intrinsic properties of engineering project. After verifying that the modified BA model is more accurately to interpret the formation mechanism of a collaborative innovation network, this paper suggests that collaborative innovation network on engineering project have their own distinctive characteristics: relativity between two nodes and attractiveness of one node. The modified BA model are imitated by using programming simulation method, experimental results show the fact that the degree distribution of nodes presents power-law distribution under the affection of relativity and attractive factor. The conclusion assist project participant chooses their cooperation partner in innovation, even design their innovation networks by application of complex networks theory.

Authors: Zhang, SJ; Ding, L
Author Full Names: Zhang Shao-jie; Ding Ling
Article Title: Comprehensive Evaluation and Analysis on Total Factor Productivity of China's Trust Industry: Based on Experience Data of 50 Trust Companies during 2008-2013
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: trust industry; total factor productivity; Malmquist productivity index; data envelopment analysis
Keywords Plus: EFFICIENCY
Abstract: This paper founds the evaluation index system first and then evaluates the total factor productivity of China's trust industry to inspect implementation effect of One Law and Two Regulations with Malmqusit-DEA methods based on date from China's 50 trust companies during 2008-2013.The result shows that the total factor productivity growth of China's trust industry grew modest during 2008-2013, lower than that before the implementation of One Law and Two Regulations. Besides, the productivity growth resulted mainly from technical progress, with negative influence of pure technical efficiency and scale efficiency. The publication of Measures for the Administration of Net Capital of Trust Companies by China Banking Regulatory Commission in September, 2010 had promoted the total factor productivity growth of trust industry. Compared with large trust companies, the productivity of small and medium-sized enterprises had made a greater progress. Overall, the expansion rates of most trust companies had exceeded the growth rate of demands, which had caused certain input redundancy.

Authors: Zhang, YT; Li, D
Author Full Names: Zhang Yun-tang; Li Dong
Article Title: The Influence Research of Brand of Origin for Consumers' Brand Preference
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: brand of origin; brand preference; local brand; overseas brand
Keywords Plus: COUNTRY
Abstract: According to the theory of consumer behavior and brand of origin effect, through the survey data statistics analysis, this paper put forward and tested the influence of the brand origin confusion on Chinese consumer preference and purchase of local brands and overseas brands. Conclusions are as follows: first, in China's existing environment, the more consumers mistake a local brand for a overseas brand, the more they will like this brand; The more Consumers mistake a overseas brand for a local brand, the more they will not like this brand. Second, the local brand awareness has a negative regulation for positive relationship between local brands origin confusion and consumers' preferences for local brands; Third, brand origin confusion has a significant negative impact on purchase of local brands.

Authors: Zhao, ZB; Cheng, X; Niu, R
Author Full Names: Zhao Ze-bin; Cheng Xin; Niu Ren
Article Title: Research on Multiobjective Portfolio Based on Corporate Social Responsibility
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: corporate social responsibility; investment preference; multiobjective portfolio; socially responsible investment
Keywords Plus: FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE; OPTIMIZATION MODEL; SELECTION
Abstract: At the initiative of sustainable development, investors take into account corporate social responsibility in a traditional portfolio gradually, socially responsible investing attract individual and communities' attention widely. Whether the performance of portfolio considered corporate social responsibility is superior to the traditional', it is worth to explore. This paper build the portfolio based on risk, return and corporate social responsibility. Then we solve the model with linear weighting method and apply it on the Chinese market, where taking into account the investors' preference. Results show that the portfolio considered corporate social responsibility can reduce risk to investors, and portfolio built by different preference investors has different degrees to reduce risk, where the risk of portfolio preferred corporate social responsibility is lowest in a long run.

Authors: Zheng, YX
Author Full Names: Zheng Yu-xian
Article Title: A Spot Stochastic Recovery Model with Levy Base Correlations
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: CDO pricing; generalized Z-process; Levy base correlations; spot stochastic recovery
Keywords Plus: DEFAULT
Abstract: In this paper, we introduce the one-factor generalized 2-process model as a copula model in solving the problem of CDO pricing. The fast fourier transform(FFT) is used to approximate the probability density function and cumulative distribution function and the cubic Hermite interpolation is used for approximating the inverse distribution function. Then we extend the model with spot stochastic recovery model, calibrate to iTraxx S9 index tranche market using both spot stochastic recovery and constant recovery and compare the results. The base correlations show that the one-factor generalized Z-process model and the spot stochastic recovery model are flexible enough to calibrate the market quotes. The correlation smile in the spot stochastic recovery case is flatter than that in the constant recovery case.

Authors: Wong, CKH; Lang, BHH; Guo, VYW; Lam, CLK
Author Full Names: Wong, Carlos K. H.; Lang, Brian H. H.; Guo, Vivian Y. W.; Lam, Cindy L. K.
Article Title: Possible Impact of Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio (ICER) on Decision Making for Cancer Screening in Hong Kong: A Systematic Review
Source Title: APPLIED HEALTH ECONOMICS AND HEALTH POLICY
Keywords Plus: COLORECTAL-CANCER; CHINESE WOMEN; REIMBURSEMENT DECISIONS; EFFECTIVENESS THRESHOLD; ECONOMIC-EVALUATION; COLONOSCOPY; NICE; CARE
Abstract: Objectives The aim of this paper was to critically review the literature on the cost effectiveness of cancer screening interventions, and examine the incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICERs) that may influence government recommendations on cancer screening strategies and funding for mass implementation in the Hong Kong healthcare system. Methods We conducted a literature review of cost-effectiveness studies in the Hong Kong population related to cancer screening published up to 2015, through a hand search and database search of PubMed, Web of Science, Embase, and OVID Medline. Binary data on the government's decisions were obtained from the Cancer Expert Working Group, Department of Health. Mixed-effect logistic regression analysis was used to examine the impact of ICERs on decision making. Using Youden's index, an optimal ICER threshold value for positive decisions was examined by area under receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC). Results Eight studies reporting 30 cost-effectiveness pair-wise comparisons of population-based cancer screening were identified. Most studies reported an ICER for a cancer screening strategy versus a comparator with outcomes in terms of cost per life-years (55.6 %), or cost per quality-adjusted life-years (55.6 %). Among comparisons with a mean ICER of US$102,931 (range 800-715,137), the increase in ICER value by 1000 was associated with decreased odds (odds ratio 0.990, 0.981-0.999; p = 0.033) of a positive recommendation. An optimal ICER value of US$61,600 per effectiveness unit yielded a high sensitivity of 90 % and specificity of 85 % for a positive recommendation. A lower ICER threshold value of below US$8044 per effectiveness unit was detected for a positive funding decision. Conclusions Linking published evidence to Government recommendations and practice on cancer screening, ICERs influence decisions on the adoption of health technologies in Hong Kong. The potential ICER threshold for recommendation in Hong Kong may be higher than those of developed countries.

Authors: Olafsson, A
Author Full Names: Olafsson, Arna
Article Title: HOUSEHOLD FINANCIAL DISTRESS AND INITIAL ENDOWMENTS: EVIDENCE FROM THE 2008 FINANCIAL CRISIS
Author Keywords: financial distress; in utero shocks; health at birth
Keywords Plus: ECONOMIC-STRESS HYPOTHESIS; BIRTH-WEIGHT; SEX-RATIOS; OUTCOMES; FETAL; HEALTH; PREGNANCY; EXPOSURE; ORIGINS; DISEASE
Abstract: This paper studies in utero exposure to the 2008 financial crisis. Exploiting the sudden and unexpected collapse of the Icelandic economy, I find that first-trimester exposure to the crisis led to a sizable and significant reduction in birth weight, increased the probability of a low birth weight (<2500 g), and decreased the probability of a high birth weight (>4000 g). I also find evidence that the collapse reduced the sex ratio, indicating selection in utero due to maternal prenatal stress exposure. My results imply large welfare losses from financial distress that have hitherto been ignored - because children with worse health at birth can expect substantially lower lifetime earnings - and suggest that economic hardships may in general exacerbate income inequalities in the long run as low-income households are typically more exposed to financial distress. Authors: Ramos, P; Almeida, A
Author Full Names: Ramos, Pedro; Almeida, Alvaro
Article Title: The Impact of an Increase in User Costs on the Demand for Emergency Services: The Case of Portuguese Hospitals
Author Keywords: copayments; indirect costs; healthcare demand; National Health Service
Keywords Plus: NATURAL EXPERIMENT; PHYSICIAN SERVICES; INTERACTION TERMS; CO-PAYMENTS; CARE; MODELS; DETERMINANTS
Abstract: Evidence on the impact of user costs on healthcare demand in universal' public National Health Services (NHS) is scarce. The changes in copayments and in the regulation of the provision of free patient transportation, introduced in early 2012 in Portugal, provide a natural experiment to evaluate that impact. However, those changes in user costs were accompanied with changes in the criteria that determine which patients are exempt from copayments, implying that simple comparisons of user rates would be biased. In this paper, we develop a new methodology to evaluate the impact of increases in direct and indirect user costs on the demand for emergency services (ES) in the presence of compositional changes in co-payment exempt and non-exempt populations. Our results show that the increase in copayments did not have an effect in moderating ES demand by paying users, but we find significant effects of the change in transport regulation. Thus, our results support the conclusion that indirect costs may be more important than direct costs in determining healthcare demand in NHS-countries where copayments are small and wide exemption schemes are in place, especially for older patients. Copyright (c) 2015 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
